title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Sampras Takes Over as No. 1
description: PETE SAMPRAS officially returned to the top spot in the ATP Tour rankings as the weekly list was released yesterday, one day after he won the Paris Open. It marks the first time he has held the No. 1 slot since April. Sampras beat BORIS BECKER in Sunday's Paris Open final. With last year's winner, ANDRE AGASSI, sidelined and losing the ranking points, Sampras gained enough points to pass him for the No. 1 spot. (AP)

title: International Paper Plans to Buy Federal Paper Board
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Federal Paper Board Company, a diversified forest products company, for about $2.7 billion in cash and stock.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about an Alabama prison for aged and disabled inmates gave an incorrect first name in some editions for a convict. The man, who has been serving a life sentence since 1946, is Sidney Merrill, not Sandy.

title: Autodesk's Shares Fall on Profit Outlook
description: Shares of Autodesk Inc. fell 8.5 percent today after the software company warned Wall Street that its fiscal- third-quarter earnings and revenues would come in significantly below expectations.

title: World News Briefs;Nephew of Nobel Winner Seized in Guatemala
description: Rigoberta Menchu, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1992, pleaded with kidnappers today to release her 22-month-old nephew, who was snatched from his mother's arms by unidentified gunmen over the weekend.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Rallies After Recent Dip As Increased Exports Are Seen
description: Wheat prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, recovering from a recent slump, bolstered by speculation of new demand for exports.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Airways Says Profit Rose by 13.2%
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that profit rose 13.2 percent in its second fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 30. The company said it earned L222 million ($351 million) compared with net income of L196 million in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues rose to L2.13 billion ($3.36 billion) from L2.02 billion.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Mourning Was Almost a Knick
description: Before he was acquired by the Heat last Friday, Alonzo Mourning was the latest bargaining chip between the Knicks and Miami. Mourning had told the Charlotte Hornets that he would only be traded to either New York or Miami, even though Lakers General Manager Jerry West nearly pulled the trigger on a deal to get Mourning.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Telekom Wins Union Backing on Cuts
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. won union backing yesterday for its plan to cut 60,000 jobs by 2000 after the company pledged to extend its moratorium on actual layoffs until the end of 1997.

title: French Survey Sex In 20th-Century Art
description: Major French art exhibitions frequently travel to the United States, but the new show at the Georges Pompidou Center, "Feminine/Masculine: The Sex of Art," is unlikely to be among them. Put bluntly, it is about sex, specifically sex in 20th-century art. And while its purpose is not to shock, it offers enough evidence of artistic fascination with sex for Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs to pass almost unnoticed.

title: A U.S. Role In Bosnia May Hinder Recruiters
description: Sgt. Charlie Pomykaj, burly in his khaki shirt and blue trousers with a red stripe down the legs, looks every ounce the Marine Corps recruiter as he works a crowd of high school students on lunch break outside class here, offering college tuition, technical skills and exotic foreign adventures to anyone who enlists.

title: Nicaraguans Begin Assault on Disease
description: Nicaraguan health officials said they have begun an all-out assault on the bacterial disease tentatively identified today as the cause of a mysterious epidemic that has killed at least 16 people.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MARQUETTE TO BUY MAKER OF MEDICAL DEVICES
description: Marquette Electronics Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the E for M Corporation of Torrance, Calif., for $12 a share, or $89 million. Two big investors in E for M, who hold a combined 30 percent of the company, have already agreed to tender their shares, said Marquette, which is based in Milwaukee. E for M's stock rose $2.375, or 26 percent, to $11.625 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Marquette's stock rose $1, to $18.75, in Nasdaq trading. Marquette said the combined company would have annual sales of more than $500 million. Both companies make cardiology monitoring and information-systems products.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE ISRAELI RIGHT;Among Hard-Liners in Hebron, Ambivalence and Brooding but Little Sorrow
description: All across Israel and wherever there were Israelis to hear them, the sirens sounded at 2 P.M. today to summon the nation to silent mourning for Yitzhak Rabin, but Shmuel Mushnik showed no grief.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: MEMORIAL RITES;U.S. Jews Come Together in Mourning Israel's Premier
description: At the United Jewish Appeal offices in Manhattan yesterday, the big-screen television did not work, so those attending a memorial service for Yitzhak Rabin had to crowd around a smaller set to watch the funeral in Israel.

title: F.D.A. Unit Backs New AIDS Drug
description: A Federal advisory panel recommended today that a new experimental AIDS drug be approved in combination with AZT, the standard therapy.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: JOBS WANE FOR FOREIGN DOCTORS IN U.S. Facing an oversupply of doctors, the Clinton Administration and Congress, in separate measures, are scaling back the Government programs that have long allowed graduates of overseas medical schools to practice in the United States, providing crucial care in the sickest, poorest neighborhoods. At the same time, medical groups, which have long tolerated if not embraced foreign doctors, are turning against them as competition for medical jobs increases in an industry that has been thrown into turmoil by budget cuts and the growth of managed care. [Page A1.]

title: Rabin Learned Tough Lesson of Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Turning Art Into Steps and a Sense of Insecurity
description: In program notes for "Le Palindrome," presented by the Philippe Saire Dance Company on Friday night at the Pace Downtown Theater, Mr. Saire writes of the gallery programs that were the genesis of the suite of three dances that his Swiss modern-dance troupe performed. He had intended to create an experimental situation in which he and his dancers would respond to the art on display and to the artists who made it. To his surprise, the art called forth not so much responses specific to each artwork as a general sense of powerlessness and insecurity.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Health Insurers Seek Rate Rise
description: Two of the state's biggest health insurers have asked for rate increases of 12 to 40 percent on a variety of Medigap policies held by 350,000 senior citizens. The policies help pay for medical bills not covered by the Federal Medicare program. The State Insurance Department stressed yesterday that the increases requested by the Prudential Insurance Company and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey would not necessarily be granted.

title: Rabin Learned Tough Lesson of Compromise;Three Jobs for Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Citing Debt Impasse, Treasury Drops Plan For Selling Securities
description: The Government today postponed the $31.5 billion in borrowing it had planned for this week because President Clinton and Congressional Republicans failed to agree on raising the $4.9 trillion debt limit.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;With No Data to Digest, Prices of Treasuries Slip
description: Without any fresh economic data to give traders direction, Treasury prices slipped in light trading yesterday.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: GAZA;For Arabs, The Anger Outweighs Scant Grief
description: On the day of Yitzhak Rabin's funeral, there was little mourning here.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Intentionally Funny Mayors
description: Mayor Sharpe James has earned a reputation as a lot of different things during his years of running New Jersey's largest city. But is he a comedian? That will be determined on Saturday when he and two other Mayors compete to see who is the nation's funniest mayor on the seventh annual "HBO Comic Relief" show. During the program, which raises money for the homeless, Mayor James will be competing against Mayor Norm Rice of Seattle and Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore, all three, by coincidence, black Democrats.

title: Washington Talk;Avalanche of Acrimony Impedes Budget Debate
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and Vice President Al Gore got into a shouting match last week at the White House, accusing each other of making dastardly attacks that poisoned the political atmosphere.

title: Perfecting the Art of Political Longevity
description: Nobody sensible is betting on the defeat of the Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, in today's election, any more than they are on the political demise of the Queens chief prosecutor, Richard A. Brown, whose term is also up.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Barilla Co., Parma, Italy, to Grey Advertising, to handle the pasta manufacturer's advertising in North and South America and Europe (excluding Italy). Young & Rubicam continues to handle the account in Italy. Grey, which will initially serve the account from London, succeeds various local agencies in countries like France, Germany and Greece; elsewhere, Grey becomes the initial agency for the brand. The billings have not been determined.

title: First Interstate Accepts Bid By First Bank
description: Rejecting a higher but hostile offer from Wells Fargo & Company, First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles agreed yesterday to sell itself to the First Bank System of Minneapolis, a company not much more than half its size.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hoechst Says Earnings More Than Doubled
description: Hoechst A.G., the German chemical company, reported yesterday that its nine-month earnings before taxes had more than doubled. Nine-month pretax profit was 3.4 billion marks, or about $2.4 billion.

title: Tokyo Journal;Japanese Prefer Blondes (In Their Ads, That Is)
description: Brian G. Banowetz, a 28-year-old former Army intelligence trainee in Oregon, flew here this year with empty pockets and big dreams.

title: Ocean Study to Start After Big Changes And a Long Delay
description: AFTER 18 months of delays and acrimonious debate over whether it would deafen whales and other marine mammals, a $35 million experiment using underwater sound to investigate the reality of global warming is scheduled to begin this week, though much modified because of protests.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Coach Guilty of Sexual Assault
description: A 38-year-old coach for a youth football team pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of sexually assaulting four of his players. The coach, George Harris, could serve up to 10 years in prison for the assaults, which took place from 1991 until his arrest in March. The four boys, now 11 to 15, have been referred to counseling. "He was a pillar of the community, which made the process even more difficult," said Michael J. Lapolla, first assistant prosecutor for Union County.

title: By Design;Tans for All Seasons
description: On runways last week, models sported tan, rosy faces.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NPC INTERNATIONAL EXECUTIVES BID FOR COMPANY
description: A group of executives at NPC International Inc., offered yesterday to buy the restaurant company for $9 a share, or $221.4 million. NPC's stock soared $2, to $8.25, in Nasdaq trading. The board of NPC, the largest Pizza Hut franchisee, said it was considering the offer from the management team led by O. Gene Bicknell, the company's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Bicknell already owns 62 percent of the 24.6 million shares outstanding. Also in the group are James K. Schwartz, president and chief operating officer, and Troy D. Cook, vice president of finance and chief financial officer. NPC, based in Pittsburg, Kan., operates 372 Pizza Hut restaurants in 11 states. It also operates Skipper's and Tony Roma's restaurants.

title: Burying a Man of Israel
description: The eyes of Israel and much of the world were on Mount Herzl in Jerusalem yesterday as Yitzhak Rabin -- soldier, political leader, peacemaker and the last representative of a founding generation that literally created the state of Israel with its bare hands -- was laid to rest.

title: Concealed-Guns Law
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 U.S. Utilities Seek Counterparts Abroad
description: Two American utilities, seeking to gain experience and profits in the deregulated industry overseas, have announced separate acquisitions of foreign electricity distributors totaling about $4 billion.

title: Market Place;Latest Mergers Driven by Cost Cuts
description: In the current merger boom, the prevailing strategy is to buy what you know. Staying in your own business, if not in your own neighborhood, makes it easier to justify the purchase price with promises of better management and ruthless cost-cutting. So the big question confronting shareholders of the acquiring companies is whether those savings are real.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were slightly lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 15.75 points, at 18,021.22. On Monday, the Nikkei edged up 8.17 points.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE SUSPECTS;Israelis Hold Assassin's Brother As Suspected Accomplice in Plot
description: The police said today that they were holding the brother of the confessed killer of Yitzhak Rabin as a suspected accomplice in the assassination.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Law Speeds Organ Transplants
description: Doctors will not be the only ones allowed to remove organs from bodies for transplants under a law signed yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. The law, designed to ease the shortage of transplantable organs, would allow the work to be done by a medical professional or technician trained by an organ procurement organization following Federal guidelines.

title: Kinsley Hired for New Microsoft Magazine
description: The Microsoft Corporation has recruited Michael Kinsley, former editor of The New Republic and co-host of CNN's "Crossfire," to start a new on-line magazine of commentary on news, politics and culture.

title: ASSASINATION IN ISRAEL;Words of Grief and Resolve From Friends and World Leaders
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by foreign leaders and friends at Yitzhak Rabin's funeral in Jerusalem yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times and the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. The speeches by Acting Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Eitan Haber were translated from the Hebrew by The Times and by official translators.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LEARNING COMPANY TO POSTPONE MERGER DECISION
description: The Learning Company said yesterday that it planned to postpone a meeting scheduled for Thursday at which stockholders would have considered a merger with Broderbund Software Inc. The decision came after last week's unsolicited tender offer from Softkey International Inc. for the educational software company, which topped the earlier bid from Broderbund Software. In a separate announcement, Softkey said it had begun soliciting Learning's stockholders to vote against the Broderbund merger. The Learning Company said it asked its stockholders to defer deciding whether to accept Softkey's tender offer until they have been advised of its position on the offer. The company also said it expected to set a new date for the special meeting.

title: New York Does Odd About-Face on Medicaid
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Aren't Desperate, Yet, With the Emphasis on Yet
description: To call Tuesday night's home opener against the Portland Trail Blazers a "must win" for the Nets is silly considering there are 80 more games left on their schedule. But the Nets understand that another poor showing like the one they endured in Toronto Friday night could do ample damage to their psyche as well as their fan support.

title: On My Mind;For Peace in Israel
description: God has given. God has taken away. Blessed be the name of the Lord.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Liz Claiborne Names Two New Agencies
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had named two agencies, Gotham Inc. and Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot, to handle separate portions of its account.

title: Abortion-Ban Bill Usurps Doctor's Part
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of N.Y.P.D., Into 'N.Y.P.D. Blue'
description: If life were a mediocre movie script, Bill Clark would be miserable.

title: POLITICAL GAINS BY PRISON GUARDS
description: In the past decade, as California has carried out the largest prison-building boom in the nation's history, a major new political force has quietly emerged: the state prison guards' union.

title: Intruder Is Charged With Attempted Murder of Canada's Premier
description: A knife-wielding intruder was charged today with trying to murder Prime Minister Jean Chretien at his official Ottawa residence early Sunday, raising questions about the Canadian leader's security arrangements.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE NEW YORKERS;In Israel, Pataki, Giuliani and Other Officials Remember Rabin
description: It seemed somehow fitting that New York, a city known as one of the world's Jewish capitals, sent its own representatives to the funeral of Yitzhak Rabin today.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Mr. Mason Is Requesting Knick Fans' Best Behavior
description: He insists it's nothing personal. But on the eve of the Knicks' season opener at Madison Square Garden, Anthony Mason was looking to infringe upon the rights of every hardened New York sports fan.

title: Kmart Seeking Lender Concessions
description: The Kmart Corporation, struggling to regain profitability, is asking lenders for concessions so it can reduce the risk of default on $681 million of debt if the company's credit rating slips below investment grade.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TWO COMPUTER COMPANIES TO MERGE IN STOCK DEAL
description: Two companies that specialize in "real time" computing -- the Concurrent Computer Corporation and the Harris Computer Systems Corporation -- said yesterday that they would merge in a stock deal. Harris Computer's shareholders would receive 9.56 shares of Concurrent for each share they own. There are about 2 million shares of Harris Computer outstanding. Shares of Concurrent, based in Oceanport, N.J., fell 3.125 cents, to $1.50, and shares of Harris Computer climbed 37.5 cents, to $13.125. After the merger Concurrent's shareowners will hold 61 percent of the combined company. The two companies, which are expected to have combined revenues of $170 million, produce computers for specialized needs -- like military or commercial simulations -- that require quick response and reliability.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JACK RUDIN is giving a talk this afternoon, not as a builder, but as a satisfied patient. Mr. Rudin, the real estate developer and philanthropist, will address 60 medical students at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: Gasoline Price Drops
description: The average pump price of gasoline dropped almost 1.5 cents a gallon in the last two weeks as retailers passed on wholesale price drops. The average price, including all grades and taxes, was $1.159 cents a gallon on Friday, according to the Lundberg Survey of 10,000 stations nationwide. That was down 1.42 cents from the survey on Oct. 20, continuing a decline that started in summer. "This is way, way, way down," the survey publisher, Trilby Lundberg, said on Sunday. "It's nearly 13 cents lower than it was in early June, when it peaked."

title: Old Hand at Finding the Oldest Hominids
description: SEARCHER and seeker, Kamoya Kimeu sometimes believes that the bones he finds speak to him.

title: Morgenthau Asks Advice On Seeking Death Penalty
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that his senior prosecutors would help him decide whether to seek the death penalty in the slayings of three members of a Harlem family who were killed during an apparent robbery.

title: Reader's Digest and PBS Agree To Television Programming Deal
description: Reader's Digest, the magazine of the middlebrow, and the Public Broadcasting Service, often considered the television programmer to the elite, announced yesterday that they were joining forces to produce, acquire and distribute new television programs throughout the world.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cable-Price Test Is Considered
description: Federal regulators are considering an experiment that would open cable television rates to the free market in one central New Jersey community. Under the Federal Communications Commission proposal, cable companies serving Dover Township would be able to do something not permitted under Federal law since 1992: compete to offer the best price, rather than charge what regulators say.

title: Mix and Match, Live and Learn;School Embraces a Dizzying Blend of Students and Tongues
description: Orlian Alvarez's face fell when he saw the grade in red marker on his social studies exam: 8 of a possible 100 points.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Losing Games and Patience, Whalers Dismiss Holmgren
description: The slumping Hartford Whalers discharged PAUL HOLMGREN as coach yesterday and replaced him with PAUL MAURICE, a 28-year-old assistant who was hired in June. Maurice is a former coach of the Detroit Junior Red Wings.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL;The Death of Rabin: An On-Line Report
description: A special report on the Rabin assassination, including articles and photos from the archives of The New York Times, is available to computer users on

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE AMERICANS;Stay the Righteous Course, Clinton Urges the Israelis
description: Accompanied by two former Presidents and a bipartisan Congressional delegation, President Clinton implored Israelis today to "stay the righteous course" and honor their assassinated leader, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, with an unflagging commitment to Middle East peace.

title: Half of World's Coastlines Are Found to Be in Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

title: Suffolk Lawmakers Stall on Chief's Budget
description: Averting an embarrassing battle the day before elections, the Republican-controlled Suffolk County Legislature today postponed final action on County Executive Robert J. Gaffney's budget, the basis of his campaign promise to cut both property and sales taxes next year.

title: ASSASINATION IN ISRAEL: THE GRANDDAUGHTER;Goodbye to a Grandfather: We Are So Cold and So Sad
description: The granddaughter of Yitzhak Rabin, Noa Ben-Artzi Philosof, 17, spoke at his funeral. Her remarks were translated and transcribed by The New York Times.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Veterans Seek Free Agency
description: Some of the elderly eligibles filed for free agency yesterday. ANDRE DAWSON of Florida, 41, LOU WHITAKER of Detroit, 38, and BRETT BUTLER of Los Angeles, 38, added their names to the list, along with CHUCK FINLEY of California and GREG GAGNE of Kansas City.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. SURGICAL PLANS TO BUY A UNIT OF E-Z-EM INC.
description: The United States Surgical Corporation, the world's largest maker and marketer of surgical staplers, said yesterday that it would acquire Surgical Dynamics Inc. from E-Z-EM Inc. for $60 million in cash. Surgical Dynamics, based in Concord, Calif., makes materials and instruments for spinal surgery. It has developed spine cages that can be implanted to provide support for patients with back injury or degenerative disease. Surgical Dynamics has completed a four-year clinical trial under control of the Food and Drug Administration and expects to receive approval in 1996 to market the system. The shares of United States Surgical, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., were unchanged at $24.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. E-Z-EM's class A stock climbed $1.125, to $9.625, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Says the Dutch Must Help Save Fokker
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said yesterday that it would not bail out its Netherlands-based Fokker aircraft unit unless the Dutch Government also contributed to a rescue effort. Fokker needs an estimated 2.3 billion guilders ($1.45 billion) in financial aid and is being kept afloat by short-term loans from Daimler.

title: When First Legislature Sits, The G.O.P. Will Be in Charge
description: Two centuries after the Constitution made a directly elected Legislature the foundation of American democracy, Nassau County followed suit today with the election of a new Legislature that appeared to be under Republican Party control.

title: Legalizing Drugs Creates More Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCI to Allow Record Buyers To Dial Up And Tune In
description: Movies on demand and interactive television will have to wait. The MCI Communications Corporation, in its first plunge into the entertainment business, plans to introduce on Wednesday what amounts to a record store that sells music over a toll-free "800" telephone number.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Leonia Against Regionalization
description: If it was not clear to local officials already, it should be now: Leonia residents want them to do everything in their power to fight a school regionalization plan aimed at desegregating the high school in neighboring Englewood. They have been speaking out against recommendations to involve their schools and others in Bergen County in state efforts to improve the racial balance at Dwight Morrow High School. A question on yesterday's ballot asking whether the mayor and Council members should take "all appropriate action" to fight regionalization was approved, 2,027 votes to 244.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Wildwood Backs Casino Plan
description: In the shadow of Atlantic City, voters opened the door for Indians to run a casino. Officials in Wildwood have proposed deeding a 2.5-acre municipal parking lot to the Delaware tribe of Oklahoma. Each year, the Delawares would give the town of 5,000 residents $8 million from casino profits. The vote endorsing the plan, which still faces an uphill battle for state and Federal approval, was 1,028 to 481.

title: A Report Criticizes Improvement Zones In New York City
description: In the first government review of the self-taxing business districts that have proliferated in New York City in the last decade, a City Council inquiry has concluded that some have abused their power and failed to deliver promised services.

title: One Pleads Guilty to Okinawa Rape; 2 Others Admit Role
description: Three American servicemen pleaded guilty today to conspiring to abduct and rape a 12-year-old Okinawa schoolgirl in a case that has caused an uproar throughout Japan. One admitted beating and raping the girl, but the others insisted that they did not actually go through with the rape.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about an agreement to protect New York City's watershed referred incorrectly to an expected increase of $7 in water rates. It would be annual, not monthly.

title: ELECTION 1995: JUDGESHIPS;2 Unwitting Bronx Candidates Savor Their Landslide Defeats
description: A pair of election losers celebrated their defeats last night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tax Cuts Would Evade Majority of Americans The Republican tax cuts now making their way through Congress would not affect what most Americans owe, a computer analysis shows. Under the big budget bill passed by the Senate last month, 68 million taxpayers, or 55 percent of all households, would see no change.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Deli-Shortcut Salad
description: WHEN you get home late and just don't feel like turning on the stove for any reason, here is a dish that you can throw together in no time.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;Abortion Pros and Cons Gain Emotional Weight
description: Standing in the rain across from the Capitol, a pregnant mother was fighting tears in explaining her abortion last year.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of prominent figures at Yitzhak Rabin's funeral, compiled by The Associated Press, included a name erroneously yesterday. Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger did not attend; former Secretaries Cyrus R. Vance and George P. Shultz did.

title: Edward Wormley, 87, Designer Of Modern Residential Furniture
description: Edward J. Wormley, a style setter in modern residential furniture in the United States for four decades, died on Friday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 87 and lived in Weston.

title: Stiffer Competition In Restaurant Guides
description: TIM ZAGAT is not an easy man to challenge. At a robust 6 feet 2 1/2 inches, the publisher of the Zagat Survey has an imposing physique, and his guide to New York City restaurants dominates the field with sales of almost a half million copies a year.

title: Races Around the Region: ERIE COUNTY;Strong G.O.P. Challenge Rebuffed
description: Dennis T. Gorski, a Democrat running for his third term as Erie County Executive, easily defeated his Republican challenger in a race that became a battleground for state Republicans and Democrats alike.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Rookie of the Year Named
description: Sweden's JARMO SANDELIN was honored yesterday as the PGA European Tour's rookie of the year. Sandelin, 28, won the Canary Islands Open in February and tied for second in the Mediterranean Open and BMW International. He finished 21st on the tour's money list with $275,000. Previous winners include TONY JACKLIN (1963) and JOSE MARIA OLAZABAL (1986). (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHUCK SCARBOROUGH, the anchor and reporter for WNBC-TV, and OSEOLA McCARTY, the 87-year-old Mississippi laundry woman turned philanthropist, have something in common: strong ties to the University of Southern Mississippi in Hattiesburg.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexican Business Trying to Create Funds to Shield Peso
description: Government and business leaders are holding closed-door negotiations on a private industry proposal to create joint funds to stabilize the peso, officials and executives here said today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Wait for Debt Limit Deal Keeps Bond Traders Quiet
description: Bond prices moved lower within a narrow range in light trading yesterday, as credit market participants continued to watch the talks in Congress about the Federal budget and the debt ceiling and showed scant reaction to economic data and comments made by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.

title: Jose Yglesias, Novelist of Revolution, Dies at 75
description: Jose Yglesias, a novelist, journalist and playwright best known for writing about Latin Americans affected by revolutions, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Step Toward Consolidation
description: There really are two Princetons: the borough, a 1.76-square-mile area encompassing the downtown area and the university campus, and the township that surrounds it, 16.39 square miles of estates and suburban businesses and homes. They share a common library, planning board and health commission, but have retained separate governments, police departments, courts and budgets.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Child Abuse Case Taints All Sides
description: Just when you might have imagined or hoped that sensational yet shaky allegations of sex rings preying on children had subsided, "Dateline" reports another outbreak. "Innocence Lost" (a title already used by "Frontline" for its disturbing accounts of a similar case in Edenton, N.C.) focuses on Wentachee, Wash., where over the last 18 months charges have flourished like the apples that are this small town's main product. The local sex-crimes detective says he has 40 to 50 suspects on his list, along with 40 to 50 victims.

title: INSIDE
description: Action Urged on AIDS Drug

title: Sports of The Times;Money Talks, But Barkley Talks Louder
description: THE last time the Knicks played a game that counted in Madison Square Garden, they suffered the indignity of watching Patrick Ewing's finger-roll shot wriggle off the rim as time and the season ended.

title: Races Around the Region: SUFFOLK COUNTY;Executive Wins Second Term Handily
description: Robert J. Gaffney, a Republican, was re-elected to a second four-year term as Suffolk County Executive, easily defeating his Democratic opponent, Tony Bullock, Supervisor of the Town of East Hampton, by a 2-to-1 ratio.

title: Book Notes
description: Poets Out of Their Youth

title: Aristide Sets Dec. 17 As Date for Election
description: Haiti today set Dec. 17 as the date for elections intended to select a new president when Jean-Bertrand Aristide's term ends in February.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Live Man Outlasts Dead Man
description: Donald Cresitello ran against a dead man and won. The outcome of the Council election was less certain than it might at first have appeared. The local Republican committee urged residents to pay their last respects by voting for George Burke, who died Sept. 22. "Unfortunately, George passed on before he was able to achieve his goal," Margit Brown, chairwoman of the Morristown Republican Committee, told voters in the town's third ward. "This, however, does not mean you cannot vote for George Burke." Last night, Mr. Cresitello, a Democrat and former Mayor and Council member, was declared the winner. He received 462 votes to Mr. Burke's 182.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A UNIT OF FIRST HAWAIIAN WILL BE SOLD
description: The Bank of New York Company signed an agreement yesterday to buy the municipal bond and trust business of First Hawaiian Bank for undisclosed terms. Bank of New York said the acquisition involved the transfer of about 20 municipal bond trustee and agency relationships. The acquisition is expected to close in the fourth quarter and will add to earnings immediately, Bank of New York said. The deal was the 10th trust acquisition in two years by Bank of New York. First Hawaiian Bank is a unit of First Hawaiian Inc., which is based in Honolulu.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Oct. 21 about a concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall misidentified the flute soloist in "The Rose Lake," by Michael Tippett. She was Elizabeth Ostling, not Amy Porter.

title: Treasury Officials Accused of Undermining Review in Whitewater Case
description: Federal regulators told the Senate today that officials in the Treasury Department had undermined a 1994 ethics review that has become the cornerstone of the Clinton Administration's defense against accusations of meddling in the Whitewater investigation.

title: Russel Metals Sells Unit
description: Russel Metals Inc. has sold Cashway Building Center, a chain of building-supplies stores, to an investor group for about $52 million. Russel, a metal distributor and processor, said the group that bought Cashway was led by Craig Graham, Cashway's chairman and chief executive. As part of the deal, Russel leased real estate to the investor group and also retained certain debt and a minority stake in the investor group. Russel said the sale was part of its strategy to sell its non-metals businesses.

title: AT LUNCH WITH;Rona Jaffe Propriety Becomes Her (Or Does It?)
description: RONA JAFFE was only 26 when her best-selling first novel, "The Best of Everything," challenged the placid world order of the 1950's. Her sharp-edged portrayal of "girls brought up to fulfill the image of what boys wanted" and "the 50's rat race toward the altar" shocked many readers, in 1958, mostly men. Career instead of marriage? Horrors!

title: World News Briefs;Possibly Ancient Carving Delays Portuguese Dam
description: Portugal's new Socialist Government stopped work today on a dam project whose waters threatened to flood caves containing Stone Age rock carvings that archeologists say are among the oldest in Europe.

title: Ocotlan Journal;For Mexican Artist, 70, All the Town's a Canvas
description: In a rooftop studio here, an aging artist is taking gentle revenge on art experts who scorned him for most of his life by painting with more energy than ever.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Get Caught Flat-Footed in Home Opener
description: The scenes were not encouraging for the courtside set at the Knicks' home opener last night: Anthony Mason leaving the floor for good in the third quarter; Michael Finley, a 6-foot-7-inch rookie leaping high over the 7-foot Patrick Ewing and dunking in a rebound; blood streaming from the side of Charles Smith's fractured nose and, finally, Charles Barkley showing he is still flammable.

title: Foreign Affairs;How About You?
description: In the wake of the murder of Yitzhak Rabin there is an understandable desire to dismiss his assassin as a lone gunman from outside the pale of Israeli political life, and to call for a period of national unity. Those impulses are wrong -- all wrong -- and the man who could have told you that best was Yitzhak Rabin.

title: World News Briefs;For Walesa, Final Results In Poland Confirm Runoff
description: Final results in the first round of Poland's presidential election were released today by the state electoral commission, showing President Lech Walesa facing a runoff with a former Communist.

title: Editorial Notebook;Cyberspace in Singapore
description: From his 37th-floor office overlooking Singapore Strait, George Yeo can survey the oil refineries and bustling dockyards that helped make Singapore the trade and financial center of Southeast Asia. But the view that interests the Minister of Information and the Arts these days is not the vista beyond his window. It is the image on the computer terminal at his desk. Mr. Yeo, like the rest of Singapore's top politicians, wants his country to be a leader in the manufacture and use of computer technology without relinquishing the Government's chokehold on the dissemination of information in Singapore.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEW LINE TO BE CREATED AT TRANSMISSION PLANT IN OHIO
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would invest $180 million at its transmission plant in Sharonville, Ohio, for a new line to produce automatic transmissions. The auto maker said the plan would result in the creation of up to 250 jobs. Ford said the investment would include new tools, machinery and other equipment at the plant, which has been in operation since 1958. The line will provide capacity for a new family of transmissions with automatic overdrive for rear-wheel-drive vehicles to be introduced in the late 1990's. The line will have the capability of producing other rear-wheel-drive transmissions.

title: No Headline
description: We're seeing an increasing number of bagel-related injuries in the emergency service." -- DR. STEPHEN ADAMS, emergency-room physician. [C1:2.]

title: Clues Sought in Dumping of 19 Guns at a School
description: The police are trying to unravel the mystery of how 19 new, high-powered handguns wound up in a trash dumpster outside a school in a quiet neighborhood here.

title: U.S. Says It Is Withholding Data From War Crimes Panel
description: Despite the Clinton Administration's insistence that people who committed war crimes in Bosnia must be brought to justice, the United States said today that it was withholding intelligence from an international court investigating the atrocities.

title: A Bumper Crop of Brandied Sour Cherries
description: SOUR cherries are a small and unpredictable crop in New York State. To be on the safe side, last spring Waldy Malouf, the chef at the Hudson River Club, arranged for the restaurant to buy the entire crop of sour cherries at Kleins Kill Farm in Germantown, N.Y.

title: Fast Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Brakes on the Revolution
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich has finally made good on his five-month-old agreement with President Clinton to set up a commission to study campaign finance reform. This may sound like good news. Yet if Congress follows this path, it will be another blow to voters' hopes that the 104th Congress would be different, that it would represent change, that it can be trusted.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Big East

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Third-Quarter Earnings Rose 43.8% at Bayer
description: Bayer A.G. said yesterday that its third-quarter pretax profit rose 43.8 percent, even as the chief executive predicted that earnings might begin to fall. The company, Germany's second-largest chemical maker, said third-quarter profit jumped to 906 million marks ($638 million), lifting nine-month pretax profit 39 percent above the period a year ago, to 3.3 billion marks.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;George Wallace as a Founding Father
description: THE POLITICS OF RAGE George Wallace, the Origins of the New Conservatism and the Transformation of American Politics By Dan T. Carter Illustrated. 572 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.

title: Sri Lanka Takes Control Of Relief Aid In Rebel Areas
description: As its advancing troops tighten their grip on the rebel-held city of Jaffna, the Government has rejected appeals from the United Nations and international relief agencies for permission to mount stepped-up independent operations to care for tens of thousands of people who have fled the fighting.

title: World News Briefs;China Will Seek a Rival For Dalai Lama's Choice
description: China said today that it was searching for its own reincarnation of the second holiest lama in Tibet to set up a rival to the six-year-old boy chosen by Tibet's exiled leader, the Dalai Lama.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about tribal elections held by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians in Connecticut referred incorrectly to the status of some participants. Michael Goodwin, who criticized the tribe's leaders, ran unsuccessfully for the tribal council. He was not disqualified, nor were any tribal members ruled ineligible to run.

title: Officer Leaves Hospital and Begins Therapy
description: With hopeful words spoken from a hospital gurney, a 29-year-old police officer paralyzed in a gunfight between the police and drug suspects in an East Village bodega last month left Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday to begin his rehabilitation.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Strong Cable Growth Helps Turner's Profits
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. yesterday reported a turnaround in earnings in the third quarter on the strength of its cable networks and the start of syndication of the television show "Seinfeld."

title: ELECTION 1995: STATEN ISLAND;Murphy, the Veteran Prosecutor, Wins Again
description: When it became clear last night that Guy V. Molinari, the most popular political figure on Staten Island, had lost his bid to become the borough's district attorney, perhaps no one was more suprised than William L. Murphy, who had held the office for 12 years but whose low profile had made him unknown to many voters at the start of the race last spring.

title: Armenia Runs Show in Disputed Enclave
description: On a recent autumn day in this town linking Muslim Azerbaijan to Christian Armenia, young soldiers, their heads newly shaved, boasted of "defending our homeland."

title: Chicago Experiment Offers Lessons, But No Verdict on Decentralization
description: Six years ago, Chicago ushered in the nation's most radical exercise in transforming the way schools are run, shifting power from a central office to principals and elected school councils at all the 553 schools in its system.

title: Seductive Appeal of Local Control Over Schools;In London, System Created 7 Years Ago Divides Politicians
description: Seven years ago, Britain's Conservative Government decided to give publicly financed schools the opportunity to govern themselves, in a sense. Under the plan, primary and secondary schools could for the first time opt out of their local educational authorities and choose to be run instead by an independent board of governors.

title: Business Chiefs to Meet This Week in Spain
description: Business leaders and government officials from the United States and Europe are gathering in Spain this week to discuss ways to lower regulatory barriers and improve the flow of goods between the trading partners.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Questions Over Teachers' PAC
description: The Newark Teacher's Union released a report yesterday that raised questions about whether a political action committee organized by the union's previous management broke the law. The report said that the Committee on Political Education spent $165,569 from 1980 to 1995; of that, almost $84,000 appears to have gone for unauthorized or unreported donations to candidates. The fund, which raised money through salary deductions of $1 per month from teachers, aides and clerks, was also never legally registered with the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission, the report said. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fuji Bank Sets Write-Off
description: Fuji Bank, one of Japan's largest commercial banks, said yesterday that it would write off by next March all the problem loans it had made to Japan's heavily indebted housing-loan companies. Fuji becomes the first major Japanese bank to declare its intention to rid itself of the bad loans in one lump sum. Most banks had been expected to take several years to write off the loans. Fuji has not disclosed its total of such problem loans. Its president, Toru Hashimoto, said Fuji would not incur pretax losses from the write-off, though he acknowledged that some other banks might if they took similar action. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE ARABS;Talks Resume, but Palestinians Worry About Keeping Self-Rule on Course
description: Talks on the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Palestinian towns and villages resumed today, after a three-day suspension because of the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin. But this did little to allay rising anxiety among Palestinians that recent events might delay the larger process toward peace and Palestinian self-rule.

title: High Court Supports U.S. On Seizures
description: Bolstering the Government's efforts to seize the assets of convicted drug dealers, the Supreme Court ruled today that defendants who agreed to forfeit their property as part of a guilty plea were not entitled to a judge's review of whether the Government was taking more property than authorized by law.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Bid Approved For British Water Utility
description: The British Government approved a takeover bid yesterday by the French utility Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. for Northumbrian Water P.L.C., Britain's 10th-largest water and sewage company. The takeover would be the first in Britain's privatized water industry. The Government backed a recommendation by its water regulator, Ian Byatt, that a takeover be accompanied by cuts in water prices of up to 15 percent.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Campbell Heads to Athens
description: The former Knick and Laker TONY CAMPBELL is close to signing a one-year contract with AEK Athens for a reported $650,000. Campbell, 33, averaged 6.8 points and 2.0 rebounds last season in 78 games for the Cleveland Cavaliers. He will replace a Denver draft choice, ANTHONY PELLE, who is out for the season because of injury. (AP)

title: Rare Verdi Sketches For 'Otello' Are Up For Sale in London
description: When the other shoe of a Verdi mystery thudded to the floor recently, few seemed to realize that there had been a first.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KODAK TO BE FREED OF MARKETING RESTRAINTS
description: After a two-and-a-half-year battle with the Federal Government, the Eastman Kodak Company has been freed of decades-old restraints intended to keep it from monopolizing the United States photographic market. The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not seek a Supreme Court appeal of a Federal court ruling setting aside consent decrees issued in 1921 and 1954 that were aimed at restraining Kodak's marketing practices. The 1921 order prohibited Kodak from making private-label film, while the 1954 order barred the company from including photofinishing costs in film prices.

title: In Texas, the 'Inner Child' Has Finger on the Trigger
description: To carry a concealed weapon here in Texas, a person must pay a $140 application fee, have no history of major crime or mental illness, demonstrate an understanding of use-of-force laws and pass a shooting proficiency test with a .38-caliber revolver or a 9-millimeter semiautomatic handgun.

title: Some Big Holders Hesitant About First Interstate Deal
description: First Interstate Bancorp's agreement to be bought by First Bank System Inc., announced on Monday, may run into problems with shareholders if Wells Fargo & Company chooses to proceed with its hostile bid.

title: Archbishop Tutu to Teach at Emory as a Visiting Professor
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican primate of Southern Africa, plans to trade his clerical vestments for a blackboard and a classroom at Emory University in Atlanta next year.

title: Journal;Jew Against Jew
description: My friend Eden spoke for many American Jews, I think, when she said she respected Yitzhak Rabin enormously without feeling particular affection for him. So she, like many of us, was taken aback by the surge of emotion she felt as the news spread Saturday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Pirates' Buyer Is Approved
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates' 15-month search for new owners neared an end yesterday when major league baseball's ownership committee authorized KEVIN McCLATCHY's purchase of the team. The Pirates' owners will vote today on the $85 million buyout. Ratification is almost a certainty; 5 of the 10 owners have joined McClatchy's group. If the owners accept, McClatchy would sign a final purchase agreement and post the remaining $2 million of his $3 million down payment.

title: Goldman, Sachs Group Strikes Deal for Rockefeller Center
description: An investor group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and including David Rockefeller struck a deal yesterday to buy Rockefeller Center from Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that is preparing to take ownership of the trophy property.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Moves in Paris Bolster Franc, Helping Dollar Rise vs. Mark
description: The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday after a Government reshuffling in France bolstered the French franc against the mark.

title: HORSE RACING;Mountain Affair Wins Stakes
description: Mountain Affair, a 2-year-old daughter of Mt. Livermore, balked and kicked for several minutes yesterday before entering the starting gate at Aqueduct, then came out flying and went on to win the Miss Grillo Stakes for her third victory in four starts.

title: NYC;With New Fare, Drivers Brace for Breakdowns (in Civility)
description: THESE are days of dread at the Manhattanville Bus Depot, on West 132d Street alongside the Henry Hudson Parkway.

title: ELECTION 1995: THE OVERVIEW;Molinari Loses Race for District Attorney on Staten Island
description: Guy V. Molinari, the powerful Borough President of Staten Island, was soundly defeated last night in his bid to unseat District Attorney William L. Murphy, the three-term Democratic incumbent who had stressed his experience as a prosecutor over his opponent's considerable political sway in the borough.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE MOURNERS;Grief and Guilt Soak Gravesite Like the Rain
description: By late afternoon today the skies had turned gray, and an chill rain soaked candles and letters placed next to the wreath-covered grave of Yitzhak Rabin at the Mount Herzl cemetery.

title: Races Around the Region: HUDSON COUNTY;Democrats Take Must-Win Race
description: Robert C. Janiszewski, the incumbent Hudson County Executive, easily defeated Bill Macchi, preserving Democratic control over the county.

title: H.M.O. Quality Called Equal, at Less Cost
description: A broad new study asserts that patients treated by health maintenance organizations and those treated by doctors in traditional medical practices had similar results, even though the H.M.O.'s cost substantially less.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Schubert and Mozart Together: Which Is More Substantial? Orchestra of St. Luke's Carnegie Hall

title: Real Estate;The first new suburban mall in nearly 20 years in the Cleveland region is going  up.
description: BIG national retailers are increasingly being drawn to the outer suburbs of Cleveland, spurring the development of the first new suburban mall in the region in nearly 20 years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MORE NOTEBOOK COMPUTERS ARE INTRODUCED BY I.B.M.
description: I.B.M. introduced a new line of Thinkpad notebook computers yesterday and lowered prices on the 755 series of Thinkpads. The International Business Machines Corporation said the new computers, the 365 series, were priced at $1,999 to $3,100. They have 10.4-inch color screens, CD-ROM drives, accelerated video performance and wireless infrared printing and file-swapping capabilities. I.B.M. cut prices on the 755 series by as much as $650.

title: 8 Million Vanishes At Union
description: For more than two decades, Teamsters Local 875, which represents truck drivers, garage mechanics, assembly-line workers, rug cleaners and grave diggers in New York City, has been scarred by accusations of graft, kickbacks and crime.

title: Regency Files For Chapter 11
description: Regency Holdings (Cayman) Inc. filed yesterday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection from creditors.

title: H&R Block Official Quits
description: H & R Block said today that Harry W. Buckley, 50, the president and chief executive of the tax services unit, had resigned effective Dec. 4. The company did not give a reason for Mr. Buckley's resignation, which came after 27 years with the company.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Biggest Stockholder in Daiwa Frowns on a Sumitomo Merger
description: Daiwa Bank's largest shareholder has reportedly thrown cold water on the idea of a merger between the troubled bank and Sumitomo Bank.

title: Harsco to Acquire Symons
description: The Harsco Corporation, an industrial products and services company, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Symons Corporation, a maker of concrete-forming equipment, in a stock transaction valued at about $27 million.

title: House Committee Passes Increase in Debt Ceiling
description: As Congress and the Administration flexed their budget muscles, House Republicans moved tonight to provide short-term borrowing and spending authority for the Federal Government, but very much on their own terms.

title: Florida Sues Carter Son And Ex-Aide
description: The State of Florida filed suit on Monday against one of former President Jimmy Carter's sons and Mr. Carter's former budget director, Bert Lance, among others, citing their involvement in an insurance company that officials said had defrauded a workers' compensation fund.

title: Organic Foods Go Mainstream
description: THIS week, shoppers can add the name Wild by Nature to a short list of organic and natural-foods supermarkets in the country that includes Mrs. Gooch's in California, Bread and Circus in New England, Fresh Fields in the East and Whole Foods Markets in the West. The first Wild by Nature store will open on Friday in what was a King Kullen supermarket on North Country Road (Route 25A) in East Setauket, L.I.

title: Races Around the Region: YONKERS;Zaleski Ousted as Mayor By a Republican Councilman
description: Mayor Terence M. Zaleski, an insurgent Democrat who took office in 1991 vowing to end political corruption and the city's fight against desegregation, was ousted last night by John D. Spencer, a Republican Councilman who branded the Mayor an isolated and ineffective leader.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE INQUIRY;Israelis Investigate Far Right; May Crack Down on Speech
description: Members of far-right Israeli fringe groups slipped into hiding today as the police sought many of them for questioning, seeking possible links with the assassination of Prime Minister Yizhak Rabin.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 3d Man Arrested in Fatal Boston Shootings
description: A third man was arrested today in the shooting deaths of four people on Monday in a Charlestown neighborhood restaurant as he arrived at a courthouse where two men, including his son, pleaded not guilty to homicide and weapons charges in the case.

title: ELECTION 1995: NEW JERSEY;New Jersey Democrats Gain 3 Seats and Respect
description: New Jersey Democrats picked up three seats in the General Assembly today, narrowing the Republicans' margin of control in the State House and giving Democrats a boost in a year of Republican dominance across the nation.

title: ART REVIEW;No Muss, No Fuss At 1995 Carnegie
description: The Carnegie International is once again falling asleep at the wheel, or at least that's the implication of the congenial assortment of painting, sculpture and video art forming the 1995 incarnation of this big survey of contemporary art.

title: Dow Chemical Hid Truth on Breast Implants;Injured Still Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: War Crimes Conflict
description: Despite its insistence that war criminals in Bosnia must be brought to justice, the United States, citing national security, said it was withholding intelligence from an international court that is investigating the atrocities. Article, page A10.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Compuserve to Settle Suit
description: Compuserve Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to settle a copyright infringement lawsuit against the company for an undisclosed amount. The class-action suit, filed in November 1993, charged the on-line service and its customers with violating the copyrights of about 900 songs owned by the Harry Fox Agency Inc., a musical rights licensing agency. The suit said the songs were copied by subscribers from the service's data bases. Compuserve, a unit of H & R Block Inc., did not say it was liable but agreed to make a payment to Harry Fox, which will divide the settlement among publishers whose songs were involved.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE MOOD;Israelis Start To Pick Up The Pieces
description: After the wrenching grief of Yitzhak Rabin's funeral and amid much lingering sorrow, both Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization pledged today to continue with the moves toward peace that cost Mr. Rabin his life and still provoke extremism across the region.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: An Arkansas Firm Is Fined By N.A.S.D.
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that it had fined a Little Rock, Ark., brokerage firm, its former president and other employees $258,400 after they agreed to settle charges that the firm's customers had been given misleading statements about the risks of mutual fund shares.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Lush Music To Match Emotions On Screen
description: Movie music is quite insistently in vogue. CD best-seller lists are cluttered with soundtrack albums these days. Most of those, however, are compilations of established pop songs used in films to evoke mood and period. The technique owes more than a bow or two to Dennis Potter's "Pennies From Heaven."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;McCann Promotes A Media Executive
description: McCann-Erickson USA, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has promoted George Hayes, a longtime media executive, to two top positions on the West Coast.

title: Seductive Appeal of Local Control Over Schools;In Los Angeles, Some Areas Plan Breakup Petitions
description: Here in Los Angeles the nation's second-largest school system is in danger of being torn apart. For years it has been criticized for low student test scores and its bureaucratic leadership. Soon, a new state law will make secession from the district easier than at any other time in the past 20 years.

title: F.D.A. Panel Urges Fast Action On Approving a New AIDS Drug
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel today recommended expedited approval of the first of a new class of drugs to fight the virus that causes AIDS.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Kotite Says He Liked What He Saw of Foley
description: Rich Kotite described Glenn Foley in such glowing phrases yesterday that it sounded as if he had been ready to anoint the youngster as the Jets' quarterback of the future.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Riley Outmaneuvers Knicks Again
description: The saga began with the Knicks getting the Miami Heat to give them $1 million and a No. 1 draft pick in 1996 to get Pat Riley as coach. It grew more intriguing when Riley called the free agent Anthony Mason and said something like, "You come here, Mase, we'll take care of you."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: BUSINESS DISTRICTS CITED FOR ABUSES

title: Powell Ends His Brief Seclusion, But Not the Big Guessing Game
description: Colin L. Powell came, he spoke and he left a travel agents' convention here today without giving any hint on whether he will run for President.

title: Nicaragua Outbreak May Be Solved
description: IN investigating an outbreak of disease that has afflicted more than 1,000 people in Nicaragua in recent weeks, Federal scientists may have solved one mystery but created another.

title: Knife Knowhow: Safety and Speed
description: It comes as no surprise to Norman Weinstein, a cooking teacher in Brooklyn, that knives are the biggest cause of injury in the kitchen. But, he says, that's not the full story. "Believe me, there are as many fruits and vegetables being mutilated as there are people," said Mr. Weinstein, who gives classes in knife skills around the country. He and other cooking teachers lament the lack of knowledge that most people have of this most basic of kitchen tools.

title: Let History Show United Nations Site Is Developer's Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Calvin Klein is withdrawing, and reshooting, some underwear ads after more complaints are heard.
description: FOR the second time in three months, Calvin Klein is embroiled in a controversy over his advertising, though this one covers -- or uncovers, to be precise -- familiar ground: his penchant for underwear ads that bare flesh.

title: Now, Give Peres a Chance
description: Even as Israel mourns the death of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, muttering grows among the experts that his successor, Shimon Peres, will never be able to muster the support for the peace process that the tough old general did.

title: Officers Ousted After Charges Of Beating Dog
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said yesterday that he had dismissed a police officer and a sergeant accused of beating a station house beagle in part because their conduct after the dog's death followed a "pattern of deceit."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Court Battle on Tyson Bout
description: LENNOX LEWIS has asked a Paterson, N.J., judge to bar the World Boxing Council from sanctioning a heavyweight championship bout between MIKE TYSON and FRANK BRUNO.

title: ELECTION 1995: HARTFORD;Voters Back Company in Close Schools Vote
description: An attempt to end Hartford's controversial experiment with private management of public schools fell short today when candidates pledged to cancel the city's contract with Education Alternatives Inc. failed to win a majority on the Board of Education.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Young Is Willing to Face Cowboys, but Not Quite Eager
description: No one wants to know whether Steve Young will play this weekend more than Steve Young.

title: Home Is Where to Filter Drinking Water
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Islanders' McLennan Performs No Magic
description: There was another new look for the Islanders, this time in goal. The result, however, remained the same.

title: HORSE RACING;Betting Australian, Without the Travel
description: The Meadowlands, which pioneered all-out, full-card simulcasting three years ago and thrived, has been noticing a "malaise" creeping over business this autumn and does not know what it means. Even so, it was a pioneer again this week by bringing the Melbourne Cup from Australia to the United States for the first time in one more example of a business reaching overseas for solutions.

title: French Premier Shuffles Cabinet, Hoping to Shore Up Confidence
description: Prime Minister Alain Juppe put a new face on his conservative Government today after six months in which he and President Jacques Chirac have seen their popularity fall precipitously.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Raw and Unruly Rhythms Leading to Euphoria Israel (Cachao) Lopez, bassist S.O.B.'s

title: The Honors Come Late For a Japanese Schindler;A Month of Tribute to Savior of Thousands
description: In 1940, as the first spasms of war struck Europe, Chiune Sugihara was an obscure bureaucrat serving as the Japanese consul in Kaunas, Lithuania. He was a kind and gentle family man, an able linguist, a typical low-level civil servant.

title: Business Travel;The White House Conference on Travel and Tourism produces a series of recommendations.
description: THE many business executives who attended last week's White House Conference on Travel and Tourism are back at their usual haunts, after having voted to carry out a series of recommendations.

title: At The Nation's Table: South Portland, Me.;Culinary Students Provide the Bargains
description: Imagine: ocean-side dining with prime rib, pate and chocolate chiffon pie. And for $7! The catch? There isn't one -- except that some of the fish may come from the ocean that diners overlook and the entire meal is prepared by students.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BALLY ENTERTAINMENT SETS HEALTH-CLUB UNIT'S SPINOFF
description: The Bally Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it planned to issue about 11.8 million shares of the Bally's Health and Tennis Corporation in a spinoff of the unit, which has been losing money. Bally Entertainment, a Chicago-based casino company, said it planned to issue one share in the unit for every four Bally Entertainment shares held by stockholders of record Nov. 15. There are 47.2 million shares outstanding. The distribution is to occur by Jan. 5. Bally Entertainment has been working on the spinoff for more than a year. Bally's Health owns about 330 fitness clubs in the United States and Canada, while Bally Entertainment owns casinos in Nevada, New Jersey, Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: Cellular Provider Sues Telefonos de Mexico
description: Grupo Iusacell S.A., a big Mexican cellular-phone company, sued Telefonos de Mexico today, accusing the huge state phone-service provider of illegal business practices.

title: Subpoenas Request Records on Fuhrman
description: The Federal authorities investigating the conduct of Mark Fuhrman, the former Los Angeles police detective who was a focal point of the O. J. Simpson case, have served subpoenas on the Police Department seeking his work records, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: Rwanda Says Army Killed 300 Hutu In 2-Day Raid
description: Government forces killed some 300 former Rwandan troops and militiamen on an island near Zaire's border in their heaviest blow yet to rebel forces, Government officials said today.

title: In Medicine of the 90's, House Calls Are to Nurses, on the Telephone
description: HELLO?"

title: COMPANY NEWS;APRIA SAYS PRESIDENT RESIGNED TO CONTROL COSTS
description: The Apria Healthcare Group said yesterday that its president and vice chairman, Timothy M. Aitken, had resigned to control costs. Apria is the result of the $1 billion merger in June of the Abbey Healthcare Group and Homedco Inc. Mr. Aitken was the chairman, chief executive and president of Abbey before the merger. "With the imminent prospect of reductions in government reimbursement, it is clear that further cost savings should be made," Mr. Aitken said. "Given that I am, and always have been, a strong advocate of the company controlling its costs, I have decided to do my part by eliminating my own position." Apria, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., provides home health services like infusion therapy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID HOCKNEY, the British artist who has lived in Los Angeles for more than 30 years, received a welcome in London yesterday worthy of a rock star. Reporters, photographers and television crews mobbed a news conference where he appeared in connection with a retrospective show of his drawings that opens tomorrow at the Royal Academy of Arts.

title: Death Penalty Case Lures Top Legal Help
description: Had Lawrence Whitehurst been arrested three weeks earlier for the murder and kidnapping of a 7-year-old girl in Kingston, N.Y., he probably would have ended up with a single court-appointed lawyer.

title: Dangers Abound for Restaurant Employees
description: IN restaurant kitchens, the ingredients are sometimes treated with more care than the employees.

title: Streamlining Jury Service, at Last
description: Chief Judge Judith Kaye has announced new rules that will add dignity and efficiency to New York State's civil justice system and make jury service a less depressing experience than it is now.

title: One Pleads Guilty to Okinawa Rape; 2 Others Admit Role;Protests by Relatives
description: Relatives of three American servicemen who pleaded guilty in a Japanese court today to the conspiracy to abduct and rape a 12-year-old Okinawa girl continued to maintain that despite the pleas, their loved ones were innocent and had been coerced to confess.

title: Ex-Student Is Found Insane in Killing of 2
description: A former law student who said he could read minds was found not guilty by reason of insanity today in the deaths of two men he shot to death near the University of North Carolina campus.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Mourning Leaves a Big Void
description: The Charlotte Hornets are letting their fans have a say about what to do with a nine-story mural bearing the faces of ALONZO MOURNING, MUGGSY BOGUES and LARRY JOHNSON. The mural, on a First Union bank building in Charlotte, N.C., must be altered because of Mourning's trade late last week to Miami. The bank and the club officials asked Hornets fans yesterday to mail in ideas for the mural, a favorite among residents and visitors to the city. (AP)

title: If Elite Columbia Students Can't Resolve Hatreds
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Repetition Is Exciting
description: Not long ago, botanists discovered that mushrooms scattered over a 30-acre area in upper Michigan were actually part of one huge fungus.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
description: The Equitable Companies reported yesterday that net earnings rose 9 percent in the third quarter, helped by gains from its brokerage and money management divisions.

title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON;A 5-Man Mission For Peace
description: One runner was hoping to qualify for the 1996 Summer Olympics. Another had been training for a year to run his first marathon. Then, 12 hours before five Israeli athletes were to board a plane for this coming Sunday's New York City Marathon, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated.

title: Consumer Debt Growth Rate Slows Sharply
description: In another sign of increasingly pinched household budgets, consumers sharply curtailed new installment debt in September, Federal Reserve figures showed today, adding to a number of recent indications that consumer spending may be running out of steam.

title: Is Your Kitchen Out to Get You?
description: ONCE a sanctuary of comfort and security, the kitchen appears to have become one big booby trap, populated by a nation of klutzes. Emergency rooms across the country report hundreds of thousands of injuries a year from treacherous tableware, out-of-control kitchen gadgets, unpredictable refrigerators and malfunctioning humans.

title: At The Nation's Table: Chicago;Creole Cooking 7 Stories High
description: Officially, it's called the New Garland Restaurant and Coffee Shop, but most Chicagoans call the little place on the seventh floor of a nondescript downtown office building "Heaven on Seven."

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 157.93 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 17,863.29. On Tuesday, the Nikkei slipped 15.75 points.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICHAEL JACKSON SELLS RIGHTS TO BEATLES SONGS TO SONY
description: Michael Jackson, the singer, sold the music publishing rights to about 250 Beatles songs yesterday to the Sony Corporation for $95 million. A new publishing venture will combine Sony's music publishing division with Mr. Jackson's ATV Music catalogue to create a business valued at $500 million. In addition to the Beatles songs, Mr. Jackson's catalogue includes songs performed by Elvis Presley and Little Richard. Publishing rights to Mr. Jackson's own songs were not included in the deal. A spokesman for Mr. Jackson did not return a telephone call seeking comment. He bought ATV in 1985 for about $47.5 million.

title: Rapper Arrested on Gun and Drug Charges
description: William Drayton, the rapper known as Flavor Flav, was arrested in the South Bronx last night for carrying an unlicensed gun and three vials of crack, the police said.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE POLITICS;Israel's Leader Declines to Call Early Elections
description: Israel's Acting Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, said today that he would not call national elections quickly, a step that would have taken advantage of the wave of sympathy aroused by the assassination of his predecessor Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Michelin U.S. Unit Agrees to Add $380 Million to 8 Pension Plans
description: Michelin North America said yesterday that it would pay $380 million to the eight pension plans of its Uniroyal Goodrich Tire unit in one of the largest settlements with the Federal agency that guarantees pensions.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NALCO CHEMICAL CO., Naperville, Ill., a maker of chemicals, bought the pulp and paper chemicals business of privately held Texo Corp., Cincinnati, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Soloing, in the Manner of Pheidippides
description: I RAN a marathon years ago. Actually, I ran several, but one was a bit different. I ran it all alone, in the summer of 1978.

title: Dow Chemical Hid Truth on Breast Implants
description: To the Editor:

title: Understand That Quebec Is Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Sister Evelyn Schneider, 84, Retired Head of St. Vincent's Hospital
description: Sister Evelyn M. Schneider, a former chief executive of St. Vincent's Hospital and superior general of the Sisters of Charity, the order that founded it 146 years ago, died on Sunday at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 84.

title: At The Nation's Table: Tuba City, Ariz.;In Total Agreement About Fried Bread
description: The Hopi Indians have lived atop mesas in the desert of northeastern Arizona for hundreds of years. Their land is surrounded by the vast Navajo Nation, and the two groups live in constant dispute over their borders. Sitting near the edge of the Hopi reservation is the Tuba City Truck Stop Cafe, a small, tattered diner where members of both nations meet over coffee.

title: Scientists Say Rain Forests Lower Levels of Global Carbon Dioxide
description: Scientists working in Brazil have found the first proof that undisturbed tropical rain forests soak up huge amounts of the carbon dioxide that people produce by burning fuels.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Personal Health;Vegetables, fruit and exercise fight arthritis, too.
description: FOR decades, people with wear-and-tear arthritis have been advised to try aspirin first to subdue the aches in their creaky joints. For those who had to take pain relievers many times a day, drug companies even produced specially coated "arthritis strength" tablets to counter the stomach irritation that can result from chronic aspirin use.

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL;The Death of Rabin: An On-Line Report
description: A special report on the Rabin assassination, including articles and photos from the archives of The New York Times, is available to computer users on

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The Real Nets Stand Up in Home Opener
description: Sometime during the Nets' home opener against the Portland Trail Blazers tonight, Coach Butch Beard had to be thinking to himself, "This is more like it."

title: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE RITES;New Yorkers Say Shalom to Rabin at Carnegie Hall
description: Carnegie Hall echoed with the "Song for Peace" yesterday as nearly 3,000 New Yorkers bid shalom to Yitzhak Rabin at a hastily organized memorial service.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Comedy of Trans-Atlantic Manners
description: Richard Nelson's "New England," which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club, is a comedy of mixed heritage about trans-Atlantic manners.

title: Lazard May Close Municipal Bond Business
description: Lazard Freres & Company has told employees it expects to decide soon whether to close its embattled municipal bond business.

title: Picasso Is King as Art Auction Tops $100 Million
description: The important fall art auctions got off to a rip-roaring start at Christie's last night as enthusiasm for Impressionist and modern art kept building, work after work. Prices soared and soared, way beyond anyone's expectations, with some paintings almost hitting the same highs they did when they were auctioned in the boom years of the late 1980's.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Amtrak Is 'Looking' After 23 Years
description: Amtrak said yesterday that it was "looking at the capabilities of other agencies" for its account, which has been handled for 23 years by DDB Needham New York. The billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURLINGTON NORTHERN SANTA FE CUTTING NONUNION JOBS
description: The Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation said yesterday that it would cut about 1,125 salaried nonunion positions this week, consolidating its work force after the $4 billion merger that created the company. The railroad, formed by the merger of Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Pacific, had said last year that it would cut 1,475 salaried, nonunion jobs after the merger. Jim Sabourin, a spokesman for the company, said that figure could be as high as 1,600 by the end of 1997. After the merger, which was completed in September, the company had about 45,000 employees, about 10 percent of whom were nonunion. The laid-off workers will be paid through the end of the year and will then receive severance packages of up to two years' salary.

title: Wine Talk
description: AUTUMN -- real autumn with brisk mornings, cold clear nights and snow scenes from Denver -- is red wine time. Cooler days call for more substantial meals and sturdier wines. What follows is an informal grouping of 15 wines that seem made for the season.
